title: MoltenVK
text:
MoltenVK is a <a href="Library%20%28computing%29">software library</a> which allows <a href="Vulkan%20API">Vulkan</a> applications to run on top of <a href="Metal%20%28API%29">Metal</a> on <a href="Apple%20Inc.">Apple</a>'s <a href="macOS">macOS</a>, <a href="iOS">iOS</a>, and <a href="tvOS">tvOS</a> <a href="operating%20system">operating system</a>s. It is the first <a href="software%20component">software component</a> to be released for the Vulkan Portability Initiative, a project to have a subset of Vulkan run on platforms lacking <a href="Native%20%28computing%29">native</a> Vulkan drivers.
There are some limitations compared with a native Vulkan implementation.
History.
MoltenVK was first released as a <a href="Proprietary%20software">proprietary</a> and commercially licensed product by The Brenwill Workshop on July 27, 2016.
On July 31, 2017, <a href="Khronos%20Group">Khronos</a> announced the formation of the Vulkan Portability Technical Subgroup.
Open source.
On February 26, 2018, Khronos announced that Vulkan became available on macOS and iOS products through the MoltenVK library. <a href="Valve%20Corporation">Valve</a> announced that "<a href="Dota%202">Dota 2</a>" will run on macOS using the Vulkan API with the aid of MoltenVK, and that they had made an arrangement with developer The Brenwill Workshop Ltd to release MoltenVK as <a href="open-source%20software">open-source software</a> under the <a href="Apache%20License">Apache License</a> version 2.0.
On May 30, 2018, <a href="Qt%20%28software%29">Qt</a> was updated with Vulkan for Qt on macOS using MoltenVK. On May 31, 2018, optional Vulkan support for <a href="Dota%202">Dota 2</a> on macOS was released. Benchmarks for the game were available the following day, showing better performance using Vulkan and MoltenVK compared to OpenGL. On July 20, 2018, <a href="Wine%20%28software%29">Wine</a> was updated with Vulkan support on macOS using MoltenVK. On 29 July 2018, the first app using MoltenVK was accepted onto the <a href="App%20Store%20%28iOS%29">App Store</a>, after initially being rejected. On 6 August 2018, <a href="Google">Google</a> open-sourced Filament, a crossplatform <a href="Real-time%20computer%20graphics">real-time</a> <a href="physically%20based%20rendering">physically based rendering</a> engine with MoltenVK for macOS/iOS. On November 28, 2018, <a href="Valve%20Corporation">Valve</a> released <a href="Artifact%20%28video%20game%29">Artifact</a>, their first Vulkan-only game on macOS using MoltenVK.
Version 1.0.
On 29 January 2019, MoltenVK 1.0.32 was released with early prototype of Vulkan Portability Extensions. <a href="RPCS3">RPCS3</a> and <a href="Dolphin%20%28emulator%29">Dolphin</a> emulators were updated with Vulkan support on macOS using MoltenVK. On 13 April 2019, MoltenVK 1.0.34 was released with support for <a href="Tessellation%20%28computer%20graphics%29">tessellation</a>. On July 30, 2019, MoltenVK 1.0.36 was released targeting Metal 3.0. On July 31, 2020, MoltenVK 1.0.44 was released, adding support for the <a href="tvOS">tvOS</a> platform. On January 23, 2020, MoltenVK was updated to support for some of the new features of <a href="Vulkan_%28API%29%23Vulkan_1.2">Vulkan 1.2</a>, as of Vulkan SDK 1.2.121. 
Version 1.1.
On October 1, 2020, MoltenVK 1.1.0 was released, adding full support for <a href="Vulkan_%28API%29%23Vulkan_1.1">Vulkan 1.1</a>, as of Vulkan SDK 1.2.154.
On 9 December, version 1.1.1 was released, providing support for Vulkan on <a href="Apple%20M1">Apple silicon</a> GPUs and support for the <a href="IOS_SDK%23Mac_Catalyst">Mac Catalyst</a> platform for porting iOS/iPadOS apps to macOS.
